You can search the Internet for the datasheet of the model you have. For example, this datasheet has the pinout at the bottom of page 2.

global.sharp

gp2y0a21yk_e.pdf

2.00 MB

Color coding is often: red power (likely 5v in this case), black ground, and light (yellow or white) is the analog signal out.

Note that the case in this example is conductive. In the old days the sensor had to be isolated from the chassis. With the relaxed rule you might get away with not doing that but Iâ€™d still isolate it.

Itâ€™s been a few years, but Iâ€™ve used that style of Sharp sensor; great sensor at low cost!
The plastic case on the ones I used served as insulation.
The ones I used were analog sensors: they produced an output voltage on the yellow line proportional to travel time, that is, reciprocal to distance. These you would connect to one of the analog in ports on the RIO. If itâ€™s a digital sensor, it would go on a DIO configured as an input, and youâ€™d have to then convert that into a number, with the required class/driver dependent on the digital format.
